posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
Hi,

I’m considering purchasing a laser cutter for my FRC team’s workshop. The primary candidate is the SWYFT 100W 35x24 CO2 laser cutter available on their website. We plan to use it for cutting plywood and MAXComposite sheets.

However, constructing a workshop that can handle external smoke and fume ventilation is proving challenging. If that’s not feasible, I wonder if an air purifier would work effectively and safely with a 100W laser cutter. Any recommendations on suitable air purifiers are greatly appreciated.

Thanks!

link_counts.title: 100W 35" x 24" CO2 Laser Cutter (Recommended for FRC Teams) – SWYFT Robotics

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Especially, we run our 40W Epilog (with air-assist) through an air purifier and only exchange air with the classroom. While cutting plywood, I notice a faint whiff of smoke, but I think this is mainly from emissions escaping the bed rather than bypassing purification. (By this, I mean the laser may have been operating during the cuts, but nothing offensive occurred.)

I wouldn't feel comfortable cutting polycarbide with this setup, though cutting wood appears fine.

It's unfortunate we're in summer, so I don't know the specific purifier model we use.

posts.name: Steven Smith
posts.cooked: Not directly answering your question, but yes, your room has windows. We used a piece of plywood with a circular hole for the exhaust vent and covered it with a window to create a temporary ventilation solution without needing to drill a hole in the exterior wall. There are likely better options available, though none match the effectiveness of simply letting the air flow naturally outside.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Please find a way to vent your laser to the outside, either through a window or a fume hood, to protect the health of everyone involved. Combustion products, especially from engineered plastics, are harmful to the lungs, and an air purifier cannot eliminate all of them.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked: A random air purifier will not work, but there are products sold specifically for filtering laser cutter fumes that will let you cut without needing an external exhaust system. We have a version of the Atmos for our Trotec laser cutter. It works, but I don’t recommend it—finding a way to exhaust outside is highly advised. The total cost of owning a laser cutter increases dramatically when filtering is involved.

link_counts.title: Exhaust systems for laser machines | Trotec Laser

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked: We vent to outside, after running it through our custom-built fume extractor. High-powered fan plus multiple filters, flexible ducting. Cuts down smoke and fumes a lot, but not 100%.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Coach 3128  - Mech, Laser, Bumpers, Fix all the Things, Travel

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: As a laser engraver, avoiding dust and fumes is crucial. While specialized air purifiers can be costly, relying solely on natural airflow often reduces particulate buildup. Using an inline fan allows me to direct smoke effectively without the need for filters, ensuring optimal performance whether I'm working with wood or CO2.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked: We have a BOFA 1500 iQ. It’s brand new, so I can’t comment on its performance, but the small filter weighs about 150lbs. Yes… we’ve heard the joke.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: BOFA is a great system. There is also Apple Air (no relations). I can’t comment on it as I don’t own either.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked: Wood tends to gum up the media used. Yeah, wood tends to gum up the media used.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I don't cut wood often... I still have to clean my inline exhaust twice a year... it's not that bad... but it's still bad enough. This is mostly from engraving. Oils and dust collect on the impeller. Fun times!
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
